developing: Presents one "perfect" solution; relies on buzzwords.
exceptional: Applies CAP Theorem; uses "Back-of-the-envelope" math to justify choices.
proficient: Acknowledges trade-offs (e.g., Latency vs. Consistency).

developing: Design fails under load; cannot explain sharding or replication.
exceptional: Proactively addresses "Hot Keys," Single Points of Failure, and Data Consistency.
proficient: Identifies bottlenecks; suggests horizontal scaling and CDNs.

developing: Missing core components (LB, Cache); data flow is broken.
exceptional: Justifies component selection; explains how data moves through every layer.
proficient: Complete "End-to-End" flow; logical placement of services and DB.

developing: No clear endpoints; schema is missing or lacks structure.
exceptional: Designs extensible APIs; justifies data model based on read/write patterns.
proficient: Designs functional APIs; chooses SQL vs NoSQL with basic reasoning.

developing: Answer was disorganized; hard to follow the timeline.
exceptional: Mastered the "Beat": Brief setup, deep "Action," and clear result.
proficient: Followed STAR clearly; easy to understand the context.

developing: Spoke mostly about what "the team" did; vague on personal role.
exceptional: Explained why they took specific actions and the trade-offs involved.
proficient: Clearly defined their specific contributions and steps.

developing: Outcome was vague or missing.
exceptional: Quantified results with data ($ or %) and linked it to business goals.
proficient: Provided a clear result (e.g., "launched on time," "fixed the bug").

developing: No mention of lessons learned or future improvements.
exceptional: Demonstrated deep self-awareness and how it changed their current habits.
proficient: Mentioned one thing they learned from the experience.

developing: Rambled; used too much jargon; low energy.
exceptional: Engaging storyteller; handled follow-up questions with ease.
proficient: Concise; professional tone; easy to follow.

developing: Starts drawing immediately; misses scale or latency goals.
exceptional: Uncovers "hidden" edge cases and defines clear Non-Functional Requirements.
proficient: Defines core features and basic scale (DAU/QPS).

developing: No clear endpoints; schema is missing or lacks structure.
exceptional: Designs extensible APIs; justifies data model based on read/write patterns.
proficient: Designs functional APIs; chooses SQL vs NoSQL with basic reasoning.

developing: Missing core components (LB, Cache); data flow is broken.
exceptional: Justifies component selection; explains how data moves through every layer.
proficient: Complete "End-to-End" flow; logical placement of services and DB.

developing: Design fails under load; cannot explain sharding or replication.
exceptional: Proactively addresses "Hot Keys," Single Points of Failure, and Data Consistency.
proficient: Identifies bottlenecks; suggests horizontal scaling and CDNs.

developing: Presents one "perfect" solution; relies on buzzwords.
exceptional: Applies CAP Theorem; uses "Back-of-the-envelope" math to justify choices.
proficient: Acknowledges trade-offs (e.g., Latency vs. Consistency).

developing: Starts coding immediately; misses edge cases (empty, null, negatives).
exceptional: Defines constraints and identifies tricky edge cases before touching the keyboard.
proficient: Asks 1-2 clarifying questions about inputs/outputs.

developing: Logic is "trial and error"; jumps into code without a clear strategy.
exceptional: Explains the chosen algorithm vs. alternatives; gets interviewer "buy-in" on the plan.
proficient: Matches problem to a pattern (e.g., Two Pointers); writes high-level pseudocode.

developing: Syntax errors; poor variable names; code is one giant, messy block.
exceptional: Writes clean, modular code; handles edge cases gracefully; avoids "spaghetti" logic.
proficient: Writes working, readable code; uses standard naming conventions.

developing: Says "I'm done" without checking; relies on the interviewer to find bugs.
exceptional: Conducts a rigorous "Dry Run" with edge cases; catches and fixes bugs independently.
proficient: Manually walks through a simple test case to verify logic.

developing: Cannot explain Big O or gives incorrect complexity analysis.
exceptional: Explains the O(n) trade-offs and suggests potential optimizations for space or time.
proficient: Correctly identifies Time and Space complexity (e.g., $O(n)$).

developing: Starts drawing immediately; misses scale or latency goals.
exceptional: Uncovers "hidden" edge cases and defines clear Non-Functional Requirements.
proficient: Defines core features and basic scale (DAU/QPS).
